abstract.text: A protocol that defines the information to provide about samples within a track of a media asset, and enables stepping through samples in the track in decode or presentation order.

inlineContent.text: This object delivers sample data either by providing sample location and sample chunk information, or by directly generating a sample buffer.
An
object can return sample data to
in two ways:
Return information about the sample data location in the media and let Core Media read the data.
Read the data and return sample buffers directly.
Review the following information that explains these approaches and which one to use for typical scenarios.

content.text: Allowing Core Media to read the sample data

inlineContent.text: This is the preferred method to deliver sample data. It allows Core Media to optimize data I/O read operations, and potentially combine multiple smaller reads into a single larger read for better performance. There are four methods available to deliver the required sample location information:
This is the baseline method to return sample location information. For formats with individually-stored samples such as video, Core Media calls this method to find each sample location.

For formats with samples stored in groups, blocks, or chunks such as audio, use this method to indicate details about the number of samples stored in each group. After determining the chunk information, Core Media calls
to locate individual samples within the chunk.
objects for these formats need to implement both
and
In some cases itâ€™s not possible to directly determine the sample location and return it through
. Instead, thereâ€™s a two-step process to determine the sample location: call
to obtain a coarse estimation, and then call
to find the exact location. Implement both methods to support this approach.
This method returns the exact sample location information as a second step after it receives the coarse estimate from
. Implement both methods to support this approach.
When itâ€™s not possible to let Core Media read the sample data using location information, the
object needs to read the sample data itself using the
to deliver the sample data buffers. This is less efficient for data I/O because thereâ€™s no way for Core Media to optimize read operations.
The method
delivers sample data buffers directly, so it allows the
object flexibility to read and unpack the samples from the media. The sample cursor needs to use the

directly to seek and read in the sample data. This method can deliver sample buffers either with one sample, such as for video tracks, or with blocks of samples, such as for audio tracks. Itâ€™s also suitable for use with synthesized samples that use metadata from the media, such as for timecode tracks.
Choose the best approach in these typical scenarios:
The media stores the samples in groups interleaved among other samples.
The
object implements
and
to allow Core Media to locate the chunks and find samples inside the chunks.
The media stores the samples in blocks interleaved among other samples, but some blocks are non-contiguous.
The
object implements
, and
. For contiguous samples,
returns the samples to read. For non-contiguous samples,
fails with the error
and Core Media then uses
to read the samples.
Itâ€™s not possible to determine sample location in one step.
The
object implements
and
(instead of
). If itâ€™s not possible to determine the sample location using either the one-step or two-step approach, the
object implements
to directly deliver sample buffers.
Itâ€™s necessary to unpack or prepare sample data before delivering it.
If Core Media canâ€™t directly read the sample data, then the
object implements
to read the data itself, unpack or prepare it, and deliver it in sample buffers.

abstract.text: Represent time-based audio-visual assets with essential data types.
This framework provides a means for developers to create format readers, video decoders, and RAW processors for media that the system doesnâ€™t natively support.
Provides read access to the data in a media asset file.
An error code that indicates specific sample isnâ€™t contiguous, spans more than one file, or is for some other reason unsuitable for reading directly from a file.
An object that provides information about the estimated sample location with the media.
An object that provides information about the HEVC dependency attributes of a sample.
A protocol that defines the information to provide about samples within a track of a media asset, and enables stepping through samples in the track in decode or presentation order.
Returns information about the chunk that holds the sample indicated by the cursor.
The decode duration of the sample at the current position.
The format description for the sample at the current position of the cursor.
The duration of the playable content starting from the cursor position.
The decode timestamp (DTS) of the sample at the current position of the cursor.
Dependency information about the sample the cursor points to.
Returns an estimate of the sample location indicated by the cursor.
Additional information thatâ€™s necessary to recover complete sample dependency information.
Asynchronously loads a dictionary that represents frame level metadata for post decode processing.
Builds a sample buffer that contains the samples at the cursor that you specify.
The presentation timestamp (PTS) of the sample at the current position of the cursor.
Produces an exact sample location based on the estimated sample location and refinement data that you specify.
Returns the location and byte source of the sample indicated by the cursor.
Tests for an earlier boundary in sample reordering.
Tests for a later boundary in sample reordering.
Moves the cursor on the decode timeline by the delta decode time that you specify.
Moves the cursor on the presentation timeline by the delta presentation time that you specify.
Moves the cursor a given number of samples in decode order.
Moves the cursor a given number of samples in presentation order.
Decoder synchronization information about the sample the cursor points to.
An object that provides information about the chunk of media at the location of a sample.
An object that provides information about the sample location with the media.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
